description: From Middle English vertu, virtue, borrowed from Anglo-Norman vertu, virtu, from Latin virtus (“manliness, bravery, worth, moral excellence”), from vir (“man”). Doublet of vertu. See virile. In this sense, displaced Old English cræft, whence Modern English craft.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Accordance with moral principles; conformity of behaviour or thought with the strictures of morality; good moral conduct. [from 13th c.]
examples: Without virtue, there is no freedom.

entries.meaning: A particular manifestation of moral excellence in a person; an admirable quality. [from 13th c.]
examples: Some men are modest, and seem to take pains to hide their virtues; and, from a natural distance and reserve in their tempers, scarce suffer their good qualities to be known  […] .

entries.meaning: Specifically, each of several qualities held to be particularly important, including the four cardinal virtues, the three theological virtues, or the seven virtues opposed to the seven deadly sins. [from 14th c.]
An inherently advantageous or excellent quality of something or someone; a favourable point, an advantage. [from 14th c.]
examples: One virtue of the present coalition government's attack on access to education could be to reopen the questions raised so pertinently by Robinson in the 1960s  […] .

entries.meaning: A creature embodying divine power, specifically one of the orders of heavenly beings, traditionally ranked above angels and below archangels. [from 14th c.]
(uncountable) Specifically, moral conduct in sexual behaviour, especially of women; chastity. [from 17th c.]
(obsolete) The inherent power of a god, or other supernatural being. [13th–19th c.]
The inherent power or efficacy of something (now only in phrases). [from 13th c.]
examples: many Egyptians still worry that the Brotherhood, by virtue of discipline and experience, would hold an unfair advantage if elections were held too soon.
